text.p: Australian Communications Minister Richard Alston released on Friday draft arrangements for the licensing and regulation of the telecommunications industry after deregulation in July 1997.
Alston said anyone would have the right to install telecommunications infrastructure for their own use and would only require a licence in order to supply services to the public.

"From July next year, we will have a truly open telecommunications market with no limit on the number of carrier licences which can be issued and no restrictions on the services carriers supply or the technologies they use," he said in a statement.
Alston said the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) would have wide powers to resolve any disputes which might arise.
The communications minister would also have the power to set up principles on which access prices were determined, he said.
An initial package of legislation addressing radiocommunications and technical regulation matters was released on August 16.
The latest package is the second tranche of the legislation with another, addressing service obligations and industry code arrangements, expected to be released in the near future.
